captions.text:
You may have heard physicists describe the
moon as being 1.3 light-seconds away, or the

sun as 8 light-minutes away, and thought "what
is this nonsense? measuring distances with

But actually, we measure distances using time
almost every day. How far is it from your

house to the store? About ten minutes. And
how far is it from New York to Boston? About
four hours. Los Angeles to Sydney? 14 hours.

But of course, what we really mean is that
the store is ten bike-minutes from your house,

New York is 4 car-hours from Boston, and Sydney
is 14 plane-hours from LA. In fact, using

time to measure distances is so useful that
I only know the distance from LA to Sydney

in plane-hours, not miles or kilometers…
though I suppose I could figure it out by

multiplying 14 plane-hours by the 550-miles-per-hour
speed of a plane to get roughly 7500 miles.

But Sydney is also 5 sailboat-weeks from LA,
7 humpback-whale months from LA, 5 message-in-a-bottle

years from LA, and 0.04 light-seconds from
LA. On the other hand, the moon is 18 airplane-days

away, 6 car-months away, and 15 whale-years
away. Which means, in fact, that a whale might

swim as far as the distance to the moon over
the course of its lifetime .

And if that's not crazy enough, sometimes
we even measure times in distance! How long

is a movie? 8,000 feet – of film! And MinutePhysics?
30 meters.

comments.text:
+tongmaa Relativity is much more than that. (And it actually directly 
contradicts your last sentence...)
comments.author: columbus8myhw

comments.text:
+columbus8myhw "...you're not taking Relativity into account at all."

Let's drop an apple here at the same moment and height that we drop an 
apple on a twin-Earth 100 lightyears away. Those two apples will hit the 
ground at the same moment, here and there - Newton. Yet, we won't see that 
duration-of-process for another hundred years - Relativity.

Our "Now" is the same moment everywhere in the universe and isn't dependent 
on electromagnetic vibrations traveling at the speed of light.
comments.author: tongmaa

comments.text:
+tongmaa I dunno, that sounds pretty... Newtonian. Meaning, you're not 
taking Relativity into account at all.

(The whole "spacetime being one thing" started with Einstein's Theory of 
Relativity.)
comments.author: columbus8myhw

comments.text:
+columbus8myhw The duration of a process can be measured by counting 1 and 
a 2 and a 3 and a 4 ...

That count could be in microseconds but it doesn't make the time used into 
an object like the process or the distance between two stars.

So, trying to make time into an object like a space/time "fabric" is just a 
science-fiction plot ... or otherwise known as pseudo-science ...
comments.author: tongmaa

comments.text:
+tongmaa I don't know about you, but I probably learned the word "time" 
*before* learning the word "duration" when I was learning to speak. You 
should define duration in terms of time, not the other way around.
comments.author: columbus8myhw

comments.text:
+tongmaa No argue with that. I really liked this video. My point wat that 
lightyear has time just in its name. Somewhat confusing, I admit, but still 
it is a distance unit like kilometer or meter. 

Maybe I am too meticulous, because I really like physics :)
comments.author: František Hrabal

comments.text:
That is true, Frantisek, but it does not make "time" into an existential 
"object". "Time" is an abstract concept used to describe distance and 
duration of processes. The reality of time is the instrument used, not the 
distance/duration it measures, and which the video more than adequately 
describes.

comments.text:
You can't get a good estimate of the distance between cities simply by 
multiplying the flying time by the plane's airspeed, because there are 
strong air currents at the planes' cruising altitude.  When possible, 
planes attempt to take advantage of favorable air currents, which can 
easily add 30 MPH. On the other hand, a plane might be stuck in an 
unfavorable current.
Great vid, though :-)﻿

comments.author: Sobakus

comments.text:
Time actually can be measured as a distance, because it's a dimension, just 
one that behaves in a strange way. If you were to measure out a second,  
rotate the space-time continuum along an axis perpendicular to time, and 
then measure out the space you'd previously marked as being a second, you 
would find that one second equals 186,000 miles. In other words, the 
spatial relationship between time and the other dimensions is c. This, in 
turn, means that a literal hypercube would appear as a massive cube 186,000 
miles on a side, which would exist for one second.

Apologies to Vilhelm, but to the OP:
It's kindergarten, not 'garden'.

From the OED:

kindergarten

noun
1(In Britain and Australia) an establishment where children below the age 
of compulsory education play and learn; a nursery school.
More example sentences
1.1(In North America) a class or school that prepares children, usually 
five- or six-year-olds, for the first year of formal education.

The spelling is because the word is actually German.

comments.author: gmakerc1

comments.text:
I'm twelve, i live in Australia and i am still learning all this. Don't say 
that i'm not good at school because i do pretty well at my age. In fact, I 
can tell you that most ADULTS don't know this stuff. We live in an awesome 
country and I'm learning everyday. And if it WAS kindie science, I wouldn't 
remember it by my age. Just because you apparently live in a country where 
everyone knows everything, remembers everything and is in a frame of mind 
about how you are supposedly BETTER than everyone else. Does not mean you 
can just belittle someone who has obviously done extensive research and 
puts time and effort into videos (and amazing ones at that) that not only 
entertain us 'comonfolk' but also lets us learn things abut planet Earth. 
If you think this is kindie science, why are badgering US about it. 
Actually make an effort to meet this person and talk to him about what 
might make his channel better. I'm sure he would be happy to have a 
conversation with him.
